In his first media interview since the violent protests at the Sterlite Copper smelter in Tuticorin, Anil Agarwal, chairman, Vedanta Resources, alludes to vested interests behind the tragic events. India produces only 2% of the world’s copper, and the rest is supplied by Canada, the Middle East, and Europe. “Right from day one, I have been saying this that this happens only in India. All the time, people take advantage of our democracy,” Agarwal tells ET’s Vatsala Gaur and Satish John in an exclusive interaction over the telephone from London.

“Copper is the most auspicious material; the world can't run without copper. The people who make copper will be relishing that they can now use our country as their market,” Agarwal rued. “Hum log zindagi bhar import karte rahenge kya (Will we keep importing all our lives)?" That is my question.”

Excerpts:


Q) More than a dozen people have died protesting against the expansion of the Sterlite Copper plant. How do you address such a tragedy?
 I am saddened by the loss of 13 innocent lives. It took place a few kilometres away from our plant. Vedanta as a responsible corporate citizen and on humanitarian grounds, we will extend all possible support to families of the deceased and severely injured. The basic premise of the protest was unfortunate, as the plant was non-operational, awaiting Consent to Operate from TNPCB. False propaganda dominated over the truth, and we will continue to bring out the truth to the general public.


Q) Did the company fail to read the situation?
It is unfortunate what happened about 5 km away from our plants. When we had the information that something like this was being planned for the 22nd, we reached out to the court and the court was quick to inform the local administration for it to be prepared… and section 144 was imposed.


Q. Given your London listing, how will you address investors concerns overseas?
We are stricter than anybody else in the world. We have room to grow our industry at least seven times more. We can supply the Indian subcontinent including Nepal, Bangladesh, from India. Hum log zindagi bhar import karte rahenge kya (Will we keep importing all our lives)? That is my question. As far as the question of environmental damage is concerned, we are stricter than other nations in the world. You will not believe that we have 25 world-best experts who look at the complete environmental aspect of the company.


Q) The key contention of protestors is that effluents are harming the ecology and also the community’s health…
I'm ready to have an independent agency to look at it. I will completely abide by the law of the land. I will come forward if something is found amiss because I am very confident that we have zero discharge (from the plant). If some independent agency comes in to verify, they are most welcome.

…We are open to scrutiny by any independent technical committee either from India or from any part of the world to prove that Sterlite Copper is among the best smelters in the world with world class environmental practices. We follow zero harm, zero discharge and zero waste policy across units.


Q) What do you think is the cause for protest by locals and how do you propose to mitigate it?
We believe that lack of awareness among various stakeholders has been the key reason for such opposition and fake activists have used this to their advantage by spreading fake news. Even before the protests started, we had the practice to invite people from various walks of life to visit our factory and witness first hand the best practices; on the same lines, we had even extended the invitation to several activists and leaders but none of them visited. We are open to meeting and clarifying the doubts of the people of Tuticorin about any aspect of the company’s operations.


Q) Are you disappointed with the Tamil Nadu government for the way it has handled the issue?
It is not right to point fingers at anybody in this situation as whatever has happened is unprecedented and everyone was caught unaware by the course taken by the protestors. Many factions within the protestors were willing to have a discussion and get their doubts clarified about the project but the separatists have hijacked their agenda in a violent manner.

My request is to keep business away from politics. I fully agree with the fact that we need a strong government but we need to keep business away from politics. All over the world, successful economies don't mix politics with business. Having said that, it is very important for the government to get to the bottom of this episode.


Q. How does Sterlite Copper compare with the two other smelters in India and with your global peers?
We produce only about 5% of the copper of the world and 95% is supplied by Canada, Middle East, Germany Europe etc. and I can stand by that our plant has been rated the best among all those plants. India has three plants producing copper- Hindustan Copper, Birla Copper and ours. We have been there for twenty years…The air quality of the area has improved than what it was ten years ago. The groundwater quality has improved and we supply all the drinking water to everybody and we have zero discharge.… We have invested more than Rs 500 crs in environmental protection measures….Right from inception, our plant works on the principle of Zero Liquid Discharge.

Q. Industrialists including you have talked about vested interests. Who are they and are they funded by foreign interest groups?
Anti-development associations/ groups have whipped up emotions of the public against several projects in Tamil Nadu and Sterlite is also a victim of such fake activism. Such activists are time and again raking up the sentiments of the public for their vested interests which have now cost the lives of innocent people. They wish to destabilize the Indian industry through orchestrating protests for various reasons.


Q. You have been under attack from NGOs etc. for Sesa Goa or at Niyamgiri….
 We are the only resources (mining) company in India. Secondly, we are the only company listed there and listed outside (LSE). And we have been openly championing about our country’s natural resources and not depend on imported coal, or iron ore, copper, crude oil..

… In the past too, other companies such as Tata, Maruti, Hindalco etc have faced such events. Unfortunately, misinformation spread by vested interests gets taken on the face value by the public at large, leading to such incidents. But it becomes dangerous when anti-social elements masquerade as activists.


Q. Are you willing to engage with the protestors?
We were always willing to have a dialogue with the protestors and address their concerns. This was even communicated to the general public and other stakeholders through print media. We even invited them to come and visit our facilities to see for themselves how we have undertaken environmental friendly initiatives. They did not respond.


Q. Some allegations levelled against you by activists, say that the plant is located 14 km's from the Gulf of Mannar when according to a condition laid down in the NOC that was given in 1994, it had to be 25 km away from the gulf.

Gulf of Mannar is not yet notified as National Marine Park as per Environmental Protection Act or as per Wildlife Protection Act. This matter was debated in detail in the Hon’ble Supreme Court (Case: Sterlite Industries (India) Versus Union of India & Ors. Etc Etc) and both State Government and Central Government accepted that it is not yet notified as National Marine Park. Moreover, the latest EIA notification prescribes a limit of 10 km from any national parks and they have also stated that in case of setting up industries within 10km then the MOEF can be approached for the same.

All allegations have already been dealt with by the Supreme court and the National Green Tribunal which has given us a favourable judgment.




Q. They have also alleged that the TN Pollution Control Board has been soft on you since the beginning….
The TN government had set up the SIPCOT industrial complex in Tuticorin within 15km from the Gulf of Mannar in the early 1980s. Since this industrial complex was meant for Red category industries, Sterlite was also allotted land in this complex when it approached the TN government in 1994. Moreover, TNPCB had laid down the stringent condition of Zero Liquid Discharge for Sterlite right from inception, which means not a single drop of wastewater can be let out of the company premises, while many industries in Tuticorin are even now allowed to let their effluents into the ocean. The presence of Zero Liquid Discharge plants means there cannot be any concern to marine life because of Sterlite Copper.

Also, we ensure that non-toxic wastes or by-products generated in a month have to be sold to sustainable applications within that month whereas several other industries in the country have huge stockpiles of such by-products. There also have been other unique and stringent conditions such a fence line monitoring, Flue gas desulphurization system which have been imposed on Sterlite Copper.

Hence conditions imposed by TNPCB are much more stringent than for other companies across the country and calling them biased towards Sterlite is completely baseless.


Q. In another event when in 2004, it was discovered that Sterlite had started production of some units of its proposed expansion without a license, and without an environment clearance?
We commenced production only after obtaining Consent from TNPCB and even the construction was started after obtaining necessary approvals. All these issues were adequately handled and deliberated in depth by the Supreme Court during 2013 and laid to rest.

Metals magnate Anil Agarwal has told ET that his group is ready to “undergo scrutiny” by any technical committee to prove to the people of Tuticorin that all the allegations against Sterlite Copper were done with “mala fide intentions” and that the unit is a victim of “fake activism”.

“Anti-development associations/groups have whipped up emotions of the public against several projects in Tamil Nadu and Sterlite is also a victim of such fake activism,” he said in an exclusive interaction, his first with the media after 13 protestors died in Tuticorin.

“Such activists are time and again raking up the sentiments of the public for their vested interests that have now cost the lives of innocent people. They wish to destabilise Indian industry through orchestrating protests for various reasons,” Agarwal told ET over telephone from London, where his Vedanta Resources Plc is listed and based.

It is not new for the oil-to aluminum, zinc and copper metals conglomerate to face opposition from environmental groups and NGOs. Agarwal, however, views them as actions by vested interests that would not like India to become self sufficient in natural resources.

“Hum log zindagi bhar import karte rahenge kya (Will we keep importing all our lives)? That is my question,” Agarwal said, when asked why his group faces repeated protests from activists.

He also debunked all talk of his group not adhering to environmental norms, stating that Vedanta had all the permissions for the copper plant to operate. The group was planning to double the production when the agitation started.

Citing instances of other Indian business groups facing similar opposition, Agarwal said activism is common, especially when the country is pushing the development agenda.

“Every industry, small or big, has faced the wrath of activists in some way or the other. In the past, too, other companies like Tata, Maruti, and Hindalco have faced such events,” he said. “Unfortunately, misinformation spread by vested interests gets taken on the face value by the public at large, leading to such incidents,” he rued.

While observers say the Tamil Nadu government was caught unaware by the agitation that turned violent, Agarwal is not willing to be drawn into finding who is at fault for allowing events to come to such a pass.

“Let us not point fingers at anybody in this situation,” he remarked, although his grouse against vested interests remains. “…it becomes dangerous when antisocial elements masquerade as activists.

And it is for the company to clear the doubts raised by such activists. We believe it is only a matter of time before people get to know the truth similar to what happened in the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant.”

NEW DELHI: Solid buying in financials, auto, pharma and oil stocks lifted domestic equity indices for third day in a row on Monday. Twin positive cues of softening crude prices and a rupee recovery boosted investors’ sentiment. 

The S&P BSE Sensex added 240.61 points to end at 35,165, while NSE’s Nifty50 gained 83.50 points to close at 10,688.

In the process, momentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, signalled upward crossovers for 151 stocks on NSE.

MACD is known for signalling trend reversals in a traded security or index.

Among the stocks that saw bullish crossovers were Jet Airways, Sun Pharma, IDFC Bank, IndianOil, SAIL, NCC, Lupin, Hindalco and Bharat Petroleum. 

Some of these counters have also been witnessing strong trading volumes lately, adding further credibility to the emerging trend.

Other stocks that saw bullish crossovers included Unitech, Oriental Bank of Commerce, NCC, Rural Electrification Corporation, Allahabad Bank, India Cements, Rashtriya Chemicals, Edelweiss Financial Services, Castrol India, Indiabulls Housing Finance and Can Fin Homes.



MACD is a trend-following momentum indicator, and is the difference between the 26-day and 12-day exponential moving averages. A nine-day exponential moving average, called the signal line, is plotted on top of the MACD to reflect ‘buy’ or ‘sell’ opportunities. 

When the MACD crosses above the signal line, it gives a bullish signal on the charts, indicating that the price of the security may see an upward movement, and vice versa.

MACD alone may not be a sufficient signal to help take an investment call. Traders should make use of other indicators such as Relative Strength Index (RSI), Bollinger Bands, Fibonacci Series, candlestick patterns and Stochastic to confirm an emerging trend. 

Retail investors should consult financial experts before buying or selling a stock based on such technical indicators.

MACD charts also signalled bearish crossovers for five stocks on NSE, indicating ‘sell’ signals. They included Nandan Denim, Manpasand Beverages, SH Kelkar & Company, Monte Carlo Fashions and GOCL Corporation.

By Swansy Afonso and Ganesh Nagarajan
India faces a copper supply shock after a state government ordered billionaire Anil Agarwal’s Vedanta Ltd. to shut down a plant permanently following deadly protests in a move that will slash nationwide output and stoke demand for imports. The company’s shares fell.

The Tamil Nadu government directed the southern state’s pollution control board to seal the 400,000 metric-ton-per-year smelter in Tuticorin in the interests of the people, it said on Monday. About 13 people died at the site last week after police opened fire as locals protested against alleged pollution.

The order to shut the smelter will reduce India’s production by about half, spurring imports as industrialization and increased consumption of cars and appliances fan demand. Vedanta had suspended output from the plant in March for maintenance, and the closure was extended as the protests mounted. The shutdown is an “unfortunate development,” and Vedanta will study the order before deciding on a course of action, the company said.

“If the closure is permanent, then what we expected to happen two years down the line will happen with immediate effect,” said Jayanta Roy, senior vice president at ICRA Ltd. In April, the local arm of Moody’s Investors Service had pegged India to flip to becoming a net importer by the next fiscal year.


Shares Sink
Vedanta shares lost as much as 6.2 percent to 237.90 rupees in Mumbai, the lowest since June. The stock has collapsed 24 percent this year, making it the worst performer among the top 10 metal companies in India. A closure of the plant would shave about $200 million to $250 million from Vedanta’s annual pre-tax earnings, according to an estimate from S&P Global Ratings.

Copper is used to make pipes and wires, and the Australian government forecast last year that India will require vastly more of the metal to feed its economy by 2035. Prices on the London Metal Exchange have rallied 22 percent over the past year, and were last at $6,882 a ton after paring an early drop.

India’s annual copper consumption is expected to almost triple to 2 million tons in the next decade, according to a projection from Hindalco Industries Ltd. Vedanta produced about 48 percent of the country’s total copper output of 842,961 tons in 2017-18, according to government data.

“So far our capacities were large enough for our total requirement, so we were a net exporter,” said Roy at ICRA Ltd. “Now, with no new capacities coming in and if almost 40 percent goes out on top of that, we will be in a deficit.”

Get ready to pay more for your electrical products and pumpsets as prices and import of copper, a raw material used in making them, have gone up ever since the closure of Sterlite’s Tuticorin copper smelter on March 27 when the plant shut down for a 15-day scheduled maintenance turnaround. The state government issued a permanent closure order on May 28.

With the plant that has the capacity to produce 4 lakh tonnes of copper per year, and meets a third of the sales in the country, being shut, user industries such as makers of electrical cables, which have seen a sharp spike in imports, are planning to increase prices following the rise in input costs.

Salzer Electronics, which makes electrical cables and wires, had to nearly double its copper imports due to the closure of the plant. The company, which was importing 100 tonnes of copper per month, has increased it to about 180 tonnes per month in the past two months.

“We will have no choice but to increase prices of electrical cables and wires as copper is the main ingredient in these products,” said R Doraiswamy, managing director, Salzer Electronics. The company was buying about 250 tonnes of copper rods every month from Sterlite’s Tuticorin plant.



“We already have 7%-8% shortage of copper wires. The closure would result in a huge shortage of copper. This would lead to higher prices,” said a senior official in the pumpsets industry. “We will have to increase pumpset prices,” he said.

Since hitting a low of ₹425 per kg on March 27, copper prices have been on a steady uptrend. It is now ruling at around ₹465 per kg in the spot market. Prices hit a high of about ₹470 per kg on May 23. Prices are ruling above the 200-day moving average levels.

Though Salzer also buys copper from Birla Copper, a unit of Hindalco Industries, the company said it would not be able to source more locally. “We would not be able to get more copper locally as the demand is very high,” a senior Salzer official said.

If the domestic demand for copper grows at the current rate of about 7%- 8%, the market is likely to turn into a deficit in the next couple of years, ratings agency ICRA has estimated in an April 4 forecast, just days after the Sterlite unit was shut for scheduled maintenance. “The scope of increasing copper production in India is limited as the refiners are already running their plants at high capacity utilisation levels,” it said.

“Hence, with demand increasing at a healthy rate, India may turn into a net importer of copper by FY2020 (2019-20) if no new plant is commissioned in this period,” the agency said. Sterlite, which is a subsidiary of UK-based Vedanta Resources plc, owns one of the two custom copper smelters in India and, according to International Copper Association (India), had a 33% market share by sales volume in fiscal 2017, which ended on March 31, 2017. The other major custom copper smelter in India is operated by Hindalco Industries.

Consumer durable companies such as Bluestar and Godrej, however, see no immediate impact owing to the shutdown. B Thiagarajan, joint managing director, BlueStar, said the copper tubes used in their air conditioners are imported and hence, the shutdown would not have much impact.


(With inputs from Aparna Desikan)

By Chandan Taparia
The Nifty50 index opened with a gap down on Wednesday, but managed to hold its support of 10,550 and bounced to the 10,650 level. However, the index remained highly volatile during the session ahead of Thursday’s F&O expiry. The index formed a bullish candle on the daily scale and got stuck in the grip of option writers.

Now, it has to continue to hold above 10,550 to extend the gains towards 10,680 and then 10,725 levels, while on the downside, supports are seen at 10,550 level.

The Nifty50 is flattish on an expiry-to-expiry basis as the April series closed at 10,617 and it hovered near the same zone. The volume weighted average price or VWAP of the entire series and week was at 10,680 and that is likely to act as an immediate hurdle. Nifty remained volatile in a broader trading range between 10,418 and 10,929 levels, but option writers kept their grip on the market for most part of the series.

It has seen lower rollover compared with the average of last six months, while roll cost was very low comparatively, which suggests a neutral market stance for the foreseeable future.

On the options front, maximum Put open interest was intact at 10,500 followed by 10,600, while maximum Call OI was at 10,800 followed by 10,700. Put writing was seen at strike price 10,500 while significant call writing was seen at 10,600 then 10,550. Options data suggested a broader trading range between 10,550 and 10,700 levels.

India VIX moved up 2.16 per cent to 13.41 level.

Bank Nifty opened with a gap down but managed to hold its support in the 25,950-26,000 zone and rebounded to 26,400 level. It remained highly volatile throughout the session. It erased intraday losses and formed a Bullish Candle, which suggests the decline was bought into.

Bank Nifty has to hold above 26,250 to witness any upward move towards 26,500 and then 26,750 levels, while on declines, major support is seen near 26,100 and 26,000 levels.

Bank Nifty is up 5.27 per cent on expiry-to-expiry basis as the April series settled at 25,010. Bank Nifty outperformed the Nifty index significantly, on buying in HDFC Bank, Kotak Bank, ICICI Bank.

Bank Nifty is trading higher than its series VWAP of 26,000, while the weekly VWAP comes near the 26,500 level. The VWAPs are now likely to act as support and resistance for the index.

Nifty futures closed flat at 10,613. Long buildup was seen in Petronet, M&M Financial, Bharat Financial, PowerGrid, Tata Elxsi, Havells, M&M, Pidilite Industries and TVS Motor while shorts were seen in Shriram Transport Finance, Motherson Sumi, Tata Motor DVR, Ambuja Cement, Hindalco and Oil India.

KOLKATA: The permanent closure of Vedanta’s Tuticorin copper smelter will reduce the company’s scale and business diversity, adding pressure to its other businesses to maintain their strong performance and make up for decline in revenue, global ratings agency Moody’s Investors Service said.

However, Moody’s said it expects Vedanta's other businesses - zinc, aluminium and oil & gas - to deliver a solid performance in the fiscal year ending March 2019, boosted by strong commodity prices and higher production volumes. While shutdown of the smelter is “marginally credit negative,” it will have no immediate impact on Vedanta's ratings, the agency added in its latest report on Friday.

On 29 May, Vedanta Resources plc announced that it received an order from the government of Tamil Nadu to close the company’s copper smelter plant in Tuticorin with immediate effect. The project faced protests from the local population, which opposed the smelter expansion because of environmental concerns.

“We expect the company’s scale, as measured by revenue for fiscal 2018, to decline by 25% to $11.5 billion from $15.4 billion. Vedanta’s reported earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) will decline by 5% to $3.85 billion from $4.1 billion proforma for fiscal 2018,” Moody’s said.

Vedanta's copper operations have generated low profitability compared to other business segments since its operational and financial performance depends upon the availability and price of copper concentrates used to produce end products such as copper bars, rods and wires. Vedanta's EBITDA margin, excluding the margin dilutive copper operations in India, was 33% in fiscal 2018 against 26% reported for the consolidated operations including it, the report said.

Moody’s added the cancellation of Vedanta’s land rights towards the copper expansion is a key concern in view of the company's ability to restart copper smelting operations. Sipcot, the Tamil Nadu state industries promotion arm, cancelled the land allotment a day after the government order on the closure of the unit.

The ratings agency said it is yet unclear as to what extent the company will be compensated for the land acquired for the expansion. “Only 26% of the $717 million capital spending was incurred until March 2018, but the company’s ability to recoup the amount spent is likely to be difficult,” it added.

Vedanta has declared a 'force majeure' clause, such that it is not able to deliver its outstanding production volumes and is not able to purchase copper concentrate. Vedanta’s copper operations had a 33% market share in copper bars and rods by sales volume in fiscal 2017, according to International Copper Association (India).

The Tuticorin smelter is one of the two copper smelters in India, with the second operated by Hindalco Industries Ltd with an annual production capacity of 5,00,000 tonne. State owned Hindustan Copper, which has its own captive mines, also has smelting operations, though it is much smaller than the other two units. While Hindalco''s copper smelter is located in Bharuch, Gujarat, Hindustan Copper has a smelter in Ghatshila, Jharkhand.

CHENNAI: Copper consuming industries are switching to a combination of imports and increased sourcing from the other large private producer Hindalco after the closure of the Vedanta-Sterlite factory cut domestic production and raised concerns over future supply. 

Industrialists, however, confirm that there is no immediate supply crisis. 

The Vedanta-Sterlite smelter accounted for 48% of the country’s refined copper production in the last fiscal. It supplied 2.5 lakh tonnes of its annual output of 4 lakh tonnes to domestic manufacturers, who use the refined copper for applications in making electrical wires, cables, tubes, motors, transformers, automotive harnesses, and other engineering products.

Sterlite exports well over of a third of its total production, according to Vedanta-Sterlite’s CEO P Ramnath. The factory’s closure, he said, is expected to cause disruption among user industries in the market. “Ideally, we should have restarted the factory by mid-May had we obtained the necessary clearances from the government,” he told ET. 

Coimbatore-based Stark Industries, which sells nearly 2,000 alternating current electric motors every month, is finding the supply of copper wires getting delayed after the shutdown of the Sterlite plant. The company sources the wires from an intermediary who converts refined copper into wires after enamelling and insulation processes. 

“The supply is not streamlined as before,” said J Nithyanandam, managing partner at Stark. “The situation now is definitely not alarming; not a crisis. But, going forward, this may hit supplies. Prices of copper wires have gone up from Rs 520 a kg to Rs 550.”

Manufacturers who had sourced from Sterlite Copper say the closure has not had any material impact, so far. A global commodity, copper is usually sourced in India through a combination of domestic suppliers and imports, with Aditya Birla Group company Hindalco and Sterlite Copper being the two large producers in the country. 

“In place of two factories in India, we have only one. This simply means that we have to plan in advance to tap external sources in the interim,” said Milan M Mehta, managing director of Precision Wires, a Mumbai-based wire manufacturer with a capacity of 35,000 tonnes a year.

Mehta said Precision had switched to a combination of imports and increased supplies from Hindalco after copper from Sterlite stopped by end of March this year. “The panic sentiment whipped up in the market is untrue because copper can be sourced from other places.”

Analysts say Sterlite’s closure will turn India from a net exporter of copper to a net importer. According to Urvisha H Jagasheth, analyst at CARE Ratings, production of domestic refined copper in India is expected to see a 36% drop in FY19. India produced 843,000 metric tonnes in FY18 and this may fall to 540,000 metric tonnes in FY19 due to the Sterlite’s closure.

In a similar closure of the Sterlite plant ordered by the Madras High Court in 2013, Vedanta Resources had imported refined copper from its Dubai unit to offset the supply loss for its customers. Due to the supply crunch, average prices of copper rods had shot up during 2013.

However, India accounts for less than 10% of global copper production, according to commodity experts, and a change in copper prices is impacted more by global concerns. “The sudden change in domestic demand-supply equation is likely to lead to an increase in domestic spot prices in the near term, but ultimately domestic prices will track LME prices and INR-USD exchange rates,” said Jayanta Roy, group head-corporate ratings at ICRA.

The Ganga has for long been split in Kanpur, with the streams diverging near the Green Park cricket stadium and then reuniting under the Kanpur Ganga Bridge, before again separating to accommodate Majhara Pipar Ehatmali in Unnao District. This summer, the stream along the right bank of the river, adjacent to Kanpur, has no water. 

What flows, instead, is a dark discharge of effluents laden with organic waste, chromium and sulphide from the tanneries in Jajmau area. The discharge from a tannery drain flows past Bangali Ghat and the ruins of a fort, to meet the lefthand stream of the Ganga under the bridge. 


The air is heavy with the smell of hydrogen sulfide. Residents hope the monsoon will bring water back to the dry bank. However, just as Ganga seems to have given up on the city, Kanpur seems to have given up on its air and water.


The industrial city in Uttar Pradesh has been trying to solve its tannery discharge problem for the past 20 years, with little progress. Today, the discharge is considered to be as high as 50 million litres a day (mld). The state government’s common effluent treatment plant can deal with only 9 mld a day. On top of that, Kanpur is now infamous for having the most polluted air among global cities, according to a World Health Organization study released in May. Fourteen of the world’s 20 most polluted cities are in India, said the report.



The president of the top industry body in Kanpur, Merchants Chamber of Uttar Pradesh, BC Lahoti, says he finds it “very embarrassing” that Kanpur has topped the list of polluted cities. It should also be an embarrassment for India, which is set to host World Environment Day celebrations on June 5.

Kanpur is home to an Indian Institute of Technology that has a Centre for Environmental Science and Engineering on its campus. Sachchida Nand Tripathi, a former head of this centre and the current head of the civil engineering department, says he has never received a request from industry or the local administration for help to improve the environment. He is working on a couple of projects on air-pollution with multi-lateral funding.



Tripathi says there is little will in Kanpur to enforce environment norms. Rakesh Jaiswal, and his NGO Eco Friends, has been fighting for a cleaner Ganga since 1994. “Our campaigns seem to have no impact on either the people or the authorities.” Even the educated in Kanpur are not worried about the air quality, says activist Mahesh Pandey. Tripathi’s research shows 20% of polluting gases in the city’s air comes from industry, while 28% comes from power plants and diesel generator sets. Burning of domestic fuel contributes 46%.



Industrial pollution is the low-hanging fruit and should be targeted first, says Greenpeace campaigner Sunil Dahiya, who was involved in writing a recent report on pollution in north India. But Tripathi is not very sure it can be done, as many polluting units are small and often run from homes. These fuel the economy of small industries.

Kanpur is not the only place caught in the industry-environment conflict. The most recent has been the protests in Tuticorin, Tamil Nadu, against Sterlite’s plan to expand its copper smelter. On May 22, police opened fire to disperse protestors who, according to a first information report, had deadly weapons.

The firing killed 13. The plant had been closed many times in the past on complaints of sulphur di-oxide emissions. The firing and the uproar after that led the state government to order the permanent closure of the plant. Sterlite is an associate of the London-listed mining giant Vedanta.

If the polluter is big, the battle also becomes large. In 2016, Hindustan Unilever signed an agreement with ex-workers of its now closed thermometer factory in Tamil Nadu’s Kodaikanal making an ex-gratia payment to settle multiple law suits seeking compensation. The move came after rapper Sofia Ashraf released a video of a song, Kodaikanal Won’t, a year earlier that talked about mercury pollution due to the plant and the resultant illness among ex-workers. The video went viral. 

Responding to queries from ET Magazine, a Hindustan Unilever spokesperson says the company is committed to supporting its former employees and cleaning up its factory area and a small area which sits on the perimeter. 



“We believe that industry and environment go hand in hand. There should be stringent and clear rules. These rules must be followed rigorously. For the overall development of a particular region, industry plays a crucial role. Therefore, it is important to ensure that industry is allowed to operate uninterrupted within the parameters that have been set. Any concern raised by the stakeholders needs to be backed by scientific evidence and facts, and not hearsay.”



Vedanta was again at the receiving end of a green battle in February 2018, when the Supreme Court ordered that all iron ore mining in Goa be stopped. Vedanta was the largest miner in the state. The Goa Foundation, led by Claude Alvares, has been fighting the mining industry for a decade, demanding sustainable exploitation of resources. Vedanta’s iron ore operations in Goa, too, have been stopped on and off since 2012 due to environment concerns and licencing issues, like its copper smelter at Tuticorin.

The country is going through some kind of an “environmental emergency”, says lawyer MC Mehta, a veteran campaigner against polluting industries. Mehta, noted for his efforts to clean up the Ganga and preserve the Taj Mahal, is a winner of the Goldman Environmental Prize, the first winner from India. The award honours grassroots environment activists. It is also called the Green Nobel.



Mehta, a resident of Delhi, can count himself luckier than another Green Nobel winner, Ramesh Agarwal. The resident of Raigarh, Agarwal has had to battle bullets. In 2012, he was shot in his legs. The case has not seen a conviction. Agarwal has been highlighting the damage caused by coal mining in Raigarh area. His fight has been against all miners. In January, he wrote to the Prime Minister seeking his intervention to grant him an arms licence as he feared for his life. The district administration had refused him a permit because a first information report was lodged against him.

There is no love lost between industry and environmentalists in India. But no matter how difficult it is, a middle ground has to be found, for the sake of development and industrial growth. Industry always pays lip service to environment and sustainability.

How much of the commitment is honoured becomes clear only much later. By then, the unit concerned is often up and running. Satish Pai, managing director of Hindalco Ltd, says industry will have to go through a “mindset change” and a “behaviour change” to become sustainable. 

“We all need to act together.” Pai says he came to Hindalco, an Aditya Birla Group company that operates 17 mines across the country, after spending almost 28 years in the oil industry. He claims to have seen the wild side of industry, having worked in Nigeria and Azerbaijan. “If you do not take care of sustainability and environment, industry will not have the licence to operate.”

Pai also stresses on the crucial role industry plays in development. Only mining will bring industry and employment to the Indian hinterland. Therefore, exploitation of mineral resources has to be allowed. But the mining industry must ensure that the area concerned continues to prosper even after minerals have been extracted and the company has stopped working in the area, he adds.

Jindal Power and Steel also says a balance has to be maintained. “Environment protection is among the topmost factors and strict compliance to the stringent environment norms is paramount, while ushering in socio-economic growth,” a spokesperson adds.



Activist Mehta says the middle path is not so difficult to find. Just follow the rules. “Coexistence is possible only if there is compliance with laws. India has the best environment laws.” What is the point of celebrating Environment Day on one day, Mehta asks. “We must work for it every day.”

What has added to the complex debate is the role played by governments and the political leadership, and the habit of being politically expedient — supporting industry at times and activists at other times, instead of just upholding the law.

Veteran environmentalist and editor of Sanctuary Asia magazine in India Bittu Sahgal says: “The system has been creatively tweaked so that up and down the chain money sluices project clearances.” He points out that in his experience of sitting on government panels for clearances of projects or deciding on important issues, he has almost always found the uncompromising expert or scientist pitted against a pliant majority, left to filing a dissent note, which would sometimes not even be placed on record.

Since 2014, the government has taken it upon itself to ease the environment clearances regime. The government went after non-government organisations (NGOs), asking them to follow norms and file their returns. There was also a squeeze on foreign funding to several NGOs. In fact, the Comptroller and Auditor General’s report last year had criticised the Centre for not following the norms on granting environment clearances to more than 200 projects.



ET Magazine spoke to three senior officials of the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, but none of them wanted to be identified. They argued that environment clearances have been granted faster in the past couple of years largely due to computerisation of the process, which started in July 2014. Empowering the ministry’s regional panels and delegating certain powers to district-level authorities for minor minerals such as sand mining also eased clearance procedures. 

There has been a sense of urgency in the clearance process because of India’s aspiration to improve its ranking in World Bank’s Ease of Doing Business. India moved up 30 slots to reach 100 (of 190 nations) in the annual ranking announced in October 2017.

However, officials insisted, faster clearances do not mean leniency. “All processes are duly followed. Domain experts, mostly retired scientists in our expert panels, ultimately have to say yes for a proposal to be cleared,” says an official.

Anshul Dhiman, deputy director of industries in the government of Himachal Pradesh, says while some issues are genuine, some are manufactured by people with vested interests. The administration has to be alert to preempt protests at an early stage, says Dhiman, who oversaw the Baddi industrial town between 2012 and 2015.

One Union environment ministry official says: “It’s incumbent on us to find out whether the concerns flagged by any section are genuine or not. At times, we find a handful of people with grudges teaming up against an industry and fomenting protests so that the industry is denied clearance. In that case, the environmental concern is a mere excuse.” Industry spokespersons, while talking off the record, are seen eager to paint activists as extortionists.



But that does not take the onus away from industry to ensure it is on the right side of the law. Chandrajit Banerjee, director general of the Confederation of Indian Industry, says: “The question of striking a balance between business and environment is increasingly irrelevant... In fact , good quality environmental ecosystem is becoming a source of comparative advantage for many industries or sectors of any economy. We have cleared the period of debate on industry and environment. We are in the phase of mainstreaming and scaling up mutual dependency between industry and environment.”

Omkar Goswami , economist and chairman of CERG Advisory, says: “Resolving these conflicts require consistent dialogues b a c ked by major environment preserving investments and significant tax treatments. Such issues have never been solved quickly. But they must be solved, as they have been over time in the US, Canada and western Europe. I hope that the central and state governments will seriously put their heads together to solve this major problem, instead of blaming each other and doing little else.”



Industry vs Environment: The Flash points

TUTICORIN: Expansion plans of Vedanta’s Sterlite Copper smelter led to protests. Police opened fire, killing 13


KODAIKANAL: In 2015, singer Sofia Ashraf released a rap video titled Kodaikanal Won’t that highlighted mercury pollution in Kodaikanal because of a HUL plant. It went viral. In 2016, HUL signed an agreement to provide for the well-being of its former employees at the thermometer factory in the hill town. Months after the HUL pact, Ashraf released another video rebutting the company’s claims, which again went viral


GOA: Vedanta, along with other local miners, had a face-off with activists led by the Goa Foundation for over a decade. It had led to a mining ban in 2012. This was revoked by the state but the Supreme Court stopped all mining here in 2018


RAIGARH: Green Nobel (Goldman prize) winner Ramesh Agarwal and his organisation, Jan Chetna, have been battling several miners for much of the past 10 years. In 2012, Agarwal was shot in his legs. Earlier this year, he wrote to the Prime Minister seeking an arms licence as his application was not approved by local authorities


MUNDRA: Greenpeace and Adani Group have been at loggerheads for some time. The environment group had brought out a report in March 2014 detailing violations by the group. The allegations were not just against the Mundra project but also against those at other places in India


DABHOL: The naphtha-based mega power project from now-defunct Enron Corporation is situated around 100 km from Mumbai. It saw a lot of protests due to environmental concerns. The protests led to arrests and other police action, and further scrutiny by human rights organisations


BHOPAL: The Bhopal gas tragedy of 1984 is often a reminder of what kind of devastation an industrial unit can cause. After Union Carbide was bought by Dow Chemicals, the new company has become a regular target of protesters demanding that it pay up for the sins of Union Carbide

KOLKATA/MUMBAI: The US decision to impose a tariff of 25 per cent on steel and 10 per cent on aluminium imports from Canada, Mexico and the EU, revoking the temporary exemption, is likely to impact metal stocks like JSW Steel, JSPL, Tata Steel, Hindalco which have exposure to export markets in the US and Europe.

“We believe that there would be short-term pressure on metal stocks due to uncertainty around material flow (particularly steel) and retaliatory measures by the affected regions,” Edelweiss Research said in its latest report.

The report said steel is more vulnerable than aluminium as concerns persist on around 18 million tonne (mt) of imports by the US (almost the entire incremental global demand) getting diverted elsewhere.

“This is likely to reduce export attractiveness of Indian steel companies, particularly JSW Steel and Jindal Steel & Power (JSPL) that might have to compete against the material diverted from the US,” Edelweiss Research analyst Amit A Dixit said in the report. While JSW Steel and JSPL, for which exports comprise almost 20 per cent of sales volume, might see pressure on pricing and volume, Tata Steel might also see pressure in its European operations to the extent of US exports, he added.

Among aluminium companies, Edelweiss said it believes Hindalco would be able to pass on the price hikes, while Vedanta should also be able to maintain its export sales given that the trade flow disruption is expected to be lower in case of aluminium.

The issue of safeguarding steel exports to the US by Tata Steel’s unit in the Netherlands amid Washington’s decision to impose tariff on this sector in Europe was discussed during a recent meeting between Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte and Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Delhi in a bid to protect mutual interest.

NEW DELHI: Volatility was the only constant in the domestic equity market during the week gone by, but thankfully both the indices ended higher for the week. The 30-share Sensex gained 0.86 per cent while the 50-share Nifty added 0.85 per cent.

While easing oil prices and good growth vibes in the economy took the Sensex 416 points higher, global issues such as political turmoil in Italy and renewed trade war fears kept investors on the tenterhooks.

Going into a new week, investors will be keenly watching the progress of monsoon and the outcome of RBI's second bimonthly policy review. Besides any change in policy rates, RBI’s inflation projection and growth outlook will influence investor behaviour, said Gaurav Jain, Director, Hem Securities.

He said Nifty has resistance around 10,900 level, which is also the previous top, and a strong support at 10,500. Chances are high that these levels will be tested going forward. 

Based on various brokerage recommendations, here are 10 stock strategies that can potentially deliver good gains over the next three weeks.


Mazhar Mohammad, Chief Strategist – Technical Research & Trading Advisory, Chartviewindia.in

Power Finance Corporation | BUY | Target Price: Rs 91 | Stop loss: Rs 77

KOLKATA: State-owned Hindustan Copper Ltd (HCL) is gearing up to cater to domestic copper demand following the shutdown of Vedanta’s copper smelter at Tuticorin by exploring the full extent of its smelting capacity.

HCL hopes to realise its entire primary smelting capacity in the July-September 2018 quarter, following renovation of its 20,000 tonne per annum (tpa) smelter at Ghatshila by June 15, company executives said.

In the second quarter of this financial year HCL will also have the option of using its entire secondary smelting capacity of 50,000 tpa at the Gujarat Copper Project. With this, its smelting capacity is expected to be 50% higher than that a year ago.

“The unfortunate incident will have an impact on the domestic market for refined copper. We want to come strongly into the market. We can sell whatever we are able to produce. We will ramp up smelter capacity though our focus remains on mining capacity,” said HCL chairman Santosh Sharma.

The closure of Vedanta’s copper smelter came after the death of 13 people in police firing on locals protesting against alleged pollution from the plant.

A recent report by credit rating agency Moody’s said: “Vedanta’s copper operations had a 33% market share in copper bars and rods by sales volume in fiscal 2017, according to International Copper Association (India).”

HCL, a relatively smaller player, is also poised to seize the opportunity to increase its market share. Its product line consists of metal-in-concentrate (MIC), copper cathode and wire rods. Sharma said while the company’s strategy is being attuned to attain flexibility of approach, prevalent market conditions will determine whether the company decides to sell refined copper or MIC.

So far, the company has been able to utilise only about 30% of its secondary smelting capacity. HCL’s name plate smelter capacity is around one lakh tpa (ltpa), though it can at best achieve 70,000 tpa since one of its smelters at Khetri remains redundant since December 2008. The state-owned copper producer has also sought the mines ministry’s nod to add greenfield smelting capacity. However, Sharma did not disclose the details of the project since it is pending approval.

Vedanta and Hindalco are the two big players in the domestic copper market, each importing around 4 ltpa and also exporting. The domestic demand is around 6 ltpa, with traders’ imports of refined copper estimated to be 2 ltpa. In Vedanta’s absence, the industry estimates the shortage to be minimised, if a portion of exports is used to cater to domestic demand.

HCL is creating new units independent of the London Metal Exchange and delinked from the vagaries of the copper market. These include a Rs 200-crore copper ore tailing project at Malanjkhand, Madhya Pradesh, due to be commissioned in July 2018. The 3.3 mtpa venture will process nearly 100 mt of ore tailings, earlier considered as waste, to yield gold, silver and copper. “This is expected to directly add Rs 60 crore to the company’s bottom line every year,” Sharma said. A similar project is being planned in Khetri, Rajasthan too.

The company also plans to monetise waste rock– the granite-like ore burden removed during extraction of copper ore. It is in talks with the Indian Railways and the surface transport ministry for supplying waste rock for use as railway ballast and in road construction. This ‘wealth from waste’ project is likely to bring in good margins of nearly Rs 50 crore per annum without any additional expenditure. Besides, HCL has received approval from the mines ministry for operating as an independent exploration company.

NEW DELHI: Most metal stocks including SAIL (up 4.66 per cent), Jindal Steel & Power (up 4.24 per cent) and Hindustan Copper (up 3.42 per cent) were trading in the positive terrain during afternoon trade on Thursday.

The Nifty Metal index was trading 2 per cent up at 3,692 around 12:30 pm. 

Shares of Vedanta (up 3.33 per cent), Tata Steel (up 2.81 per cent), JSW Steel (up 2.12 per cent) and Hindalco Industries (up 1.93 per cent) were also among the top gainers in the metal pack.

Nalco (up 1.46 per cent), MOIL (up 1.29 per cent), NMDC (up 1.22 per cent), APL Apollo Tubes (up 0.66 per cent) and Hindustan Zinc (up 0.20 per cent) were also at the gainers' end.

However, Jindal Stainless (Hisar) (down 0.72 per cent) and Coal India (down 0.67 per cent) were the two losers in the index around that time.

Positive global cues and sustained buying in all sectors were keeping bourses aloft.

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 112 points at 10,797, while the BSE Sensex was up 382 points at 35,561.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 40 were trading in the green, while 10 were in the red. 

Vedanta, Axis Bank and Tata Steel were leading the pack of Nifty gainers, while Coal India, Titan and Indian Oil Corporation were among the top losers in the Nifty index.

The equity market had a relatively stable and strong session on Thursday despite the NSE benchmark Nifty coming off nearly 50 points from the high point of the day. The index finally settled 83.70 points or 0.78 per cent lower.

Though gains were observed across board, the stocks and sectors, which received a good beating in the previous few sessions, saw some value buying from the lower levels.

From the structure on the charts, the upmove is likely to continuing on Friday as well. A modestly positive start can be expected, but in the same breath, the zone of 10,820-10,845 will offer resistance at higher levels. At these levels, we see market taking a breather and entering into some fresh consolidation before any decisive move.

Friday will see the levels of 10,820 and 10,850 acting as potential resistance zone. Supports may come in at 10,735 and 10,680 zones.

The Relative Strength Index (RSI) on the daily chart is 58.3524. The RSI has marked a fresh 14-period high, which is bullish, but it does not show any divergence against the price. The daily MACD has reported a positive crossover and is now bullish while trading above its signal line. On the candles, a ‘Rising Window’ occurred. It is essentially a gap, which implies continuation of the upmove.

Pattern analysis suggests that the market has got some steam left. However, these upmoves will find resistance in the 10,820-10,850 zones as this happens to be a major pattern area resistance for Nifty.

Overall, the momentum may persist in the market, and we may still continue to see the dips, if any, being used to make quality purchases. However, in the pursuit of momentum, the zones of 10,820-10,850 are expected to offer formidable pattern resistance to the market.

We recommend continuing making fresh purchases with each opportunity that volatility offers, but at the same time, profit needs to be vigilantly protected at higher levels, as the possibilities of some volatility and profit taking cannot be ruled out if the Nifty tests 10,820-10,850 zones.

Chakri Lokapriya, CIO and MD, TCG AMC, tells ET Now that the focus is on large, well-run companies with visible earnings growth in the midcap space.Edited excerpts:

The big news this morning is the fact that after nearly three decades, the truck axle load factors are going to be up to 20-25%. How big a positive could this turn out to be for logistics?
More than logistics, the usual fleet operators, Shriram Transport type of companies will benefit. Second, there us still room for Ashok Leylands of the world to benefit. The company is well positioned. These are the companies that I would focus more on because the logistics companies have slightly different issues facing them as well. 


What about commodities? Copper and aluminium are touching multi-month highs once again. If the commodities trade intact, can somebody look at buying Tata Steel or Hindalco even at these levels?
 The latest data coming out says US is at full employment levels, which is a phenomenal thing to do and the economy is really strong. Very robust numbers are coming out. Europe is also doing fine. There has been some noise in the last couple of weeks about Italy, but the developed countries are doing well and in this environment, metals companies do well. 

Some of the metal companies have corrected recently. The frontline players like Tata Steel and Hindalco would do far better than some of the smaller companies or the government owned metal companies.


You have been tracking real estate for a while. After a great run last year, some of these stocks have paused of late. Is it time to take a relook and would Prestige be on your radar at all?
Real estate stocks are well positioned because there are pockets of regional players like Prestige in the south or maybe Godrej in the west. These are the companies which are going to benefit because of RERA. Again, the smaller players are finding it tough while the larger players are gaining share. 

Second, given how the economy has evolved in the last couple of years, there is a huge amount of unsold inventory of real estate still out there and now it is being priced out. So, against this backdrop, that is beginning to being reflected in the valuations. So, RERA gaining market share and selling down of inventory will help the bigger regional real estate players.


PSU banks led by SBI are going to be meeting with the interim Finance Minister Piyush Goyal today. Do you expect something substantial?
I hope a resolution of how they are going to treat loans to the power sector comes out of this meeting. If they try to follow the RBI classification of February 12th of one day delay, it becomes an NPA then that is really going to help. I would focus on some kind of clarification by the RBI relaxation on NPA norms for power sector loans. 

Of course, capital raising is a bigger issue for the banks but I doubt further capital infusion is going to happen in the immediate future, other than what has already been announced by former Finance Minister Arun Jaitley.


How are you looking at your investment in the financial space? NBFCs have delivered an excellent set of numbers, but they are expensive. The consolidation of PSU banks is under way and private banks are a bit of a differentiated trade?
 We are underweight on financial services overall as a space. Within that, we are looking at selective NBFCs like Magma Fincorp. It is an inexpensive stock, trades at 1.5 times book, benefits from commercial vehicle loans and benefits from small ticket loans.

The company has gone through a huge amount of restructuring. A new management is in place delivering on earnings in Shriram Transport. On the other hand, we are staying away from some of these corporate private banks and among the PSU banks, we will still have to stick to the larger ones because the government is talking about the larger banks buying out or JVs absorbing the smaller banks. We are sticking to the SBIs of the world.


We are sitting at Rs 67.51 against the dollar. Will the currency tailwind benefit the IT pack for some more time to come? 
Yes, IT as a sector will continue to benefit: a) because of the demand in developed markets and b), the currency is a tailwind. Companies like HCL Technologies, in particular, has corrected quite a lot in the last couple of weeks. Many other stocks like Tata Elxsi, TCS are looking attractive in the IT sector. We would continue to be buyers of IT as a pack.


It looks like the move in the last two days both for the benchmarks as well as the broader markets was rather a feeble one. Do you continue to keep a close eye on midcaps that have fallen quite a bit or do you wait because it does not appear to have settled down yet?
We would look at midcaps because even SEBI has now changed the definition of midcaps and any company which is less than Rs 30,000 crore is supposed to be a mid-cap. That means these are very large companies. We are looking for midcap or largecap companies with visible demonstrated earnings growth potential for next two years. There are a number of companies like that. For example, Phillips Carbon which supplies raw material to the metal space, has corrected a lot, but is still at an extremely attractive valuation. 

There are tons of large, well run companies with visible earnings growth, which we would focus on within the midcap space.

NEW DELHI: Shares of Usha Martin surged 20 per cent in morning trade on Friday, reacting positively to the media reports that Tata Steel has shown keen interest in buying the Kolkata-based steel producer.

On May 29, Vedanta announced that it received an order from the Tamil Nadu government to close the company’s 4 lakh tonne per annum (ltpa) copper smelter plant in Tuticorin with immediate effect. The project faced protests from the local population opposing the smelter expansion because of environmental concerns, leading to a loss of 13 lives in police firing.

It is ironic that in the hieroglyphics of ancient Egypt, ‘ankh’, the symbol for copper, was believed to represent life. The abrupt decision threatens to stall almost half of the country’s copper output since Vedanta had a 48% share of the 842,961 tonnes of the metal produced in India in 2017-18. This is slated to have a significant impact on the domestic copper market in the medium to long term.

According to International Copper Association (India), Vedanta had a 33% market share in copper bars and rods in fiscal 2017. Tuticorin smelter is one of the two copper smelters in India, with the second one being operated by Hindalco Industries Ltd with an annual production capacity of 5 ltpa. State owned Hindustan Copper (HCL), the only producer with captive mines, also has smelting operations, though it is much smaller than the other two units.


PRICE IMPACT
With Vedanta accounting for a third of the country’s copper supplies, the shutdown will drive up copper prices at a time when domestic copper demand is showing a firm uptick. India’s copper consumption has been growing at an average annual rate of 5.9% in the last 10 years led by electrical and transport sector needs. 

The government’s thrust on electric vehicles is also slated to boost copper demand in the next 5-10 years. Prices did react, almost immediately. A day after the closure, it was reflected in an increase in copper futures price on MCX, the country’s largest commodity exchange, which coincided with a depreciation of the rupee against the US dollar, amplifying the magnitude.

While 3-month rolling forward copper on London Metal Exchange (LME) was flat at $6856 a tonne, the near-month contract on MCX traded up 1% at Rs 464 a kilo. Analysts remained divided on the reason behind the differential in MCX and LME prices. It was believed to be an indication of the markets beginning to factor in supply pressure from the closure of the Tuticorin plant.

While the immediate supply crisis in the near to medium term can be averted, analysts are worried about the longer-term impact on the copper market. “It looks like this could take 3-6 months to get resolved. Ahead of the general elections, the plant’s problems have become a political issue,” Kishor Ostwal, chairman CNI Research said.


DOWNSTREAM IMPACT
n the medium term, it will affect over 800 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the downstream electricals industry sector that the Vedanta smelter catered to. It is also a major supplier of copper to the country’s defence sector and to infra, cement and fertilisers sectors. While it could lead to copper imports, the shutdown will also hurt India’s copper exports, as 1.6-2 lt of the production is sold internationally. 

The move to shut down the Tuticorin facility may also push up global copper prices to an extent, analysts said. At current price of $6865 per tonne, the import of 240,000 tonne of copper (net of export) will cost the nation an additional $2 billion per annum. 

“Since Vedanta Sterlite is one of the largest copper producers in the country, manufacturers in sectors ranging from electrical to defence will have to turn to imports and that will push up the nation’s annual import bill by an estimated $2 billion based on the current price,” P Ramnath, CEO, Sterlite Copper said. Vedanta currently holds a 36% market share in India’s refined copper demand. In its latest report, global ratings agency Moody’s said the shutdown will reduce Vedanta’s scale and business diversity, with fiscal 2018 revenues likely to shrink by 25% to $11.5 billion from $15.4 billion.


SUPPLY IMPACT
Between them, Hindalco and Ved anta have 9 ltpa capacity and while state-owned Hindustan Copper Ltd or HCL has a nameplate capacity of one ltpa, it can at best produce 70,000 tpa. India’s demand for refined copper is estimated at around 6.75 to 7 ltpa. That leaves a surplus of around 2 ltpa, which constitute exports. HCL chairman Santosh Sharma said this week the company will take all possible steps to explore its full smelting potential. 

Its primary 20,000 tpa smelter at Ghatshila in Jharkhand will be up and operational by June 15 after renovation. It is also stretching itself to realize the full smelter capacity of 50,000 tpa at its Gujarat Copper Project. Since June and July see seasonally low demand, the real impact is likely to be felt only from the Oct-Dec 2018 quarter. And, if a part of the exports is diverted the shortfall due to Vedanta closure can be addressed, industry watchers pointed out. This is what Hindalco, which has just commissioned a new 2.4 ltpa rod mill, seems to be doing.

“We set this up to cater to the rising demand for more volumes of rods in the Indian market. As a consequence, export commitments for this year in any case were on the lower side. In the current situation, with a slight downward adjustment in export shipments, Hindalco is trying to cater to the domestic demand,” it said in a statement. With copper sales up by 8% in FY18 to 408KT, Hindalco’s new cast copper rod plant commissioned in Q4 nearly doubled its capacity of CCR to 4.84 ltpa in Gujarat. CCRs used in agrochemicals, automobiles, consumer durables, electrical equipment, railways, wire and cable industry have been witnessing a supply demand gap in the domestic market.

Kotak Institutional Equities has a buy call on Hindalco Industries Ltd. with a target price of Rs 315. The current market price of Hindalco Industries Ltd. is Rs 231.2. Time period given by the brokerage is a year when Hindalco Industries Ltd. price can reach defined target. . Hindalco Industries Ltd., incorporated in 1958, is a largecap company with a market cap of Rs 51905.60 crore. 


Investment rationale by Kotak

We expect Hindalco to benefit from multiple earnings tailwinds across businesses as (1) aluminum recycling spreads have improved to multi-year highs in the US, (2) BRL/US$ rate has weakened sharply—both of these can act as strong triggers for Novelis. In India, higher aluminum prices (partially hedged), improved copper premiums and weaker INR/US$ will aid earnings. Over the long term, we remain positive on the aluminum price outlook due to continued deficit outside China and fast declining inventories. The soon-to-be published policy by China on captive coal fired plants can lift costs and prices. We maintain BUY with a target price of Rs 315.

ET Intelligence Group: The highly-leveraged balance sheets of Indian companies, which caused concern among investors and deterred fresh capital infusion over the past few years, are gradually showing signs of recovery. The net debt of India Inc relative to the operating profit before depreciation (net debt/EBITDA ratio) was at a four year low in FY18.

According to the ET Intelligence Group’s analysis of the BSE500 companies excluding banks, finance and software companies, net Debt-EBIDTA ratio fell to 2.5 in FY18 from 3.3 in FY15. This was largely due to higher increase in the EBITDA compared with the increase in debt.

The ratio of net debt (total debt less cash and equivalents) and EBITDA is widely used to measure the debt paying ability of a company. A ratio below three is considered healthy. The total debt of the sample increased 8 per cent to Rs 20.2 lakh crore. During the same period, EBITDA increased by 35 per cent to Rs 8.04 lakh crore.

The deleveraging was mainly driven by the improved earnings of the commodity companies, thanks to the reversal in the global commodity prices. This is also expected to revive the capex cycle.

The net debt-EBITDA ratio of the BSE500 metals and mining companies in FY18 was less than one compared with 3.7 in FY16. Thanks to improved earnings, all major metal and mining companies including Tata Steel, Vedanta, JSW Steel and Hindalco have given a strong capex guidance (including expansion through acquisitions) over the last one year. These companies together are expected to incur capex of over Rs 70,000 crore in FY19.

Similar trends are observed in other heavily-indebted industries such as real estate where the ratio fell to 4.6 from 6.2 three years ago; for textiles, the ratio dropped to 2.6 from 2.9 and for the power companies, it was marginally down to five from 5.4 by a similar comparison.

The only sector which has seen increased debt concerns is the telecom sector. Major contributors to this include Reliance communications followed by Idea.

CHENNAI: Appearing for the state government in the hearing of a batch of petitions regarding the Vedanta-Sterliet factory in Thoothukudi, Tamil Nadu Advocate General Vijay Narayan submitted with the Madurai Bench of the Madras High Court that the Government Order permanently shuttering the corporate copper smelter in Thoothukudi was a reflection of a "policy decision" to shut down the factory. 

"The policy decision was taken at the highest-level in government, by none other than the Honourable Chief Minister," advocate General Narayan confirmed with ET as his submission with the Madurai bench of the Madras High Court on Friday. 

The advocate General's submissions today arrive after the Bench comprising judge CTSelvam and judge AM Basheer Ahmed had asked the government if the Government Order permanently closing the factory had been backed by a policy decision. With the Advocate General's submissions today, the court disposed of a writ petition by MDMK chief Vaiko against the Environment Clearance given to the second phase of expansion to the smelter to raise capacity to 8 lakh tonnes a year. 

Since April 9 this year, the state government headed by Edappadi K Palaniswami had executed a series of measures against Vedanta-Sterlite, beginning with refusal to grant the Consent to Operate licence for the period 2018-2023 on grounds of non-fulfilment of conditions on pollution control and environment impact mitigations. After the police firing that killed 13 people in the protests against the factory on May 22, the state pollution control board had issued a closure order after it found the factoy had undetaken measures to restart the unit. On May 28, the state government, through a GO, had permanently closed the factory. The state land bank monitor SIPCOT had subsequently withdrawn the land allotted for the second smelter. As another blow, the state informed by way of reply to an activist that it had also withdrawn the Consent To Establish, an important licence to start a factory, for the second unit. 

The Vedanta-Sterlite unit has been shut since March 27 this year. Its CEO P Ramnath had told ET in an earlier interview that the factory should have restarted after its scheduled annual maintenance mid-May. The Sterlite factory is a key copper supplier for the state besides Aditya Birla Group's Hindalco and the Government-owned Hindustan Copper.

Vivek Mavani, Independent Investment Advisor talks to ET Now about his favourites in auto, pharma, OMCs and commodity sectors.Edited excerpts:


Does Tata Motors seem to be the haziest story in the auto pack right now?
Yes and it is not that the street is just discovering that now! Tata Motors has been a rank underperformer compared to Nifty as well as other auto stocks in the last three years. That stock has either not given returns or has been in the negative in last 12 to 18 months.
We can see a change in growth trajectory in Bajaj Auto and some of the other companies but in Tata Motors, the uncertainty on growth continues. More than 80% of earnings come from the JLR but a big question remains on how sustainable the growth is for JLR in China, Europe or US. The tariffs war development may be a couple of months old, but the Tata Motors growth disappointment or underperformance has been going on for at least 8 to 10 quarters now.


Among auto stocks, which would be your top bet? Please do not say Maruti.
Among auto stocks, in terms of two-wheeler companies Hero MotoCorp and Bajaj Auto are the preferred bets . Otherwise, Maruti is a high conviction bet on declines. It has been on a slight downtrend where according to technical analysts, the supports lie. Fundamentally, in terms of valuations at about 80 times one year forward and about 16% to 18% growth being sustained for the next at least two-three years led by volumes, led by new product and variant launches, Maruti is a terrific story going ahead.


OMCs were highlighted in trade yesterday. They have had a rough patch in the last six months. A good 25% to 30% odd correction has already played out in OMCs for the last quarter or so. Is there merit in nibbling into OMCs?
OMCs had a dream run between 2015 and 2016-17 on back of low oil prices and lower underrecoveries/subsidy contributions. We are back to the scenario of five years ago with high crude prices and under recoveries and oil PSUs taking that additional burden because the consumer prices cannot be raised in line with crude prices. That is one side of the story. I would be neutral to negative on as far as the oil OMCs -- IOC, HP, BP -- are concerned. 

In HPCL, there is an additional complication of a merger with ONGC going through. That is going to cause some sort of disturbance in the stock price as well.


How are you placing yourself in pharma?

Vivek Mavani: I will break up pharma into three parts. Fortunately, all the three parts of pharma seem to be firing as far as the growth is concerned. If we look at the Indian pharma focussed on exports, they have had a rough run over the last two-three years on back of regulatory and USFDA and quality issues.

The Halol unit of Sun Pharma getting certified a few days back is a huge shot in arm and a huge trigger on the export side. Domestic pharma has continued to consistently deliver earnings growth quarter of 15% odd, quarter after quarter, year after year.

Cipla is a very interesting bet really. Among the midcaps, Cipla has no regulatory issues and a consistent growth story. Alkem and Ajanta Pharma are again interesting domestic consumption plays. 

The third leg which has been a rank underperformer over the last 12-13 years have been the multinational pharma companies. They seem to be coming back very strongly. Glaxo or AstraZeneca were forgotten names. I am sure an entire generation of young traders and investors probably have never even looked at some of these companies which were darlings of the markets may be 15 to 25 years ago. That segment seems to be coming back in a major way and I see lot of opportunities in multinational pharma as well.


Do you have a call on Rites or Fine Organics?
I have not really looked at Fine Organics. But the other IPO which is closing today, Rites is quite an interesting play. It is a consultancy business, asset light, with high return on capital, return on equity and generates free cash flows. It is also a debt-free company in the infrastructure consulting space. Major part of work is coming from railways and capex is being planned out over the next 5-10 years. Rites could be sustainable. It has a steady earnings growth story with the hefty payouts for investors going forward. Valuation too is also not very demanding. Rites is something worth investing in both in the IPO and on listing and the oversubscription numbers at the end of second day itself speaks about it.


Coming on the commodities basket, is there still merit in looking at a Hindalco, Tata Steel as well as Vedanta at these levels?
Commodities are an interesting sector. The China factor seems to be coming back but for a different reason. In commodities, I am not so bullish on Tata Steel or Hindalco but some of the other names like Jindal Steel and Power, which has a huge deleveraging story over the next two-three years. The gross debt would come down by almost Rs 15,000 crore from about Rs 42,000 crore of peak debt in 2017.

In the next 18 months or so, the gross number should be around Rs 28,000-29,000 crore and driven by higher volumes which would jump from about 3.5 million tonnes to about 6 million tonnes by 2020. On back of higher prices, higher volumes, higher prices and a meaningful debt reduction, JSPL looks a better bet than Tata Steel. 

In the non-steel category, Hindustan Zinc looks attractive because zinc prices are still at elevated levels and Hindustan Zinc is quite an interesting bet with free cash flows, tonnes of surplus cash sitting on the balance sheet and expected hefty dividend payouts.

When the Government of India will divest the 26% stake nobody knows but assuming that does not happen in the near future, just the earnings growth and dividend payouts are enough triggers for me.

Manas Jaiswal of manasjaiswal.com has a sell call on Hindalco Industries Ltd. with a target price of Rs 214. The current market price of Hindalco Industries Ltd. is Rs 222.5. Time period given by the analyst is Intra Day when Hindalco Industries Ltd. price can reach the defined target. Manas Jaiswal recommended to keep stoploss at Rs 226. Hindalco Industries Ltd., incorporated in 1958, is a largecap company with a market cap of Rs 49952.40 Crore) operating in Metals - Non Ferrous sector. 

 Hindalco Industries Ltd. key Products/Revenue Segments include Alumina which contributed Rs 19982.76 Crore to Sales Value (50.73 % of Total Sales) and Copper/Copper Products which contributed Rs 19400.36 Crore to Sales Value (49.26 % of Total Sales)for the year ending 31-Mar-2017. 

 For the quarter ended 31-03-2018, the company has reported a Standalone sales of Rs 11681.10 Crore, up 5.97 % from last quarter Sales of Rs 11022.82 Crore and up 5.94 % from last year same quarter Sales of Rs 11026.09 Crore Company has reported net profit after tax of Rs 376.97 Crore in latest quarter. 

The company’s top management includes Mr.Askaran Agarwala, Mr.Debnarayan Bhattacharya, Mr.Girish Dave, Mr.Kailash Nath Bhandari, Mr.Kumar Mangalam Birla, Mr.Madhukar Manilal Bhagat, Mr.Praveen Kumar Maheshwari, Mr.Ram Charan, Mr.Satish Pai, Mr.Yazdi Dandiwala, Mrs.Rajashree Birla.
